clinical_study.brief_title: Posture and Pulmonary Function of Mouth-breathing Children
clinical_study.official_title: Posture and Pulmonary Function of Mouth-breathing Children

lead_sponsor.agency: Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro

clinical_study.source: Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to characterize the posture and respiratory function of mouth-breathing children.

detailed_description.textblock: Mouth-breathing children presents changes in stomatognathic system, which results in head projection, tension augment in scapular belt muscles and postural adaptations. Although thoracic shape and posture can influence ventilatory dynamics, we didn't find studies addressing pulmonary function of mouth-breathing children. This was a transversal study, designed to analyze the posture of mouth-breathing children, and verify the existence of correlation between posture and pulmonary volumes.

primary_outcome.measure: Pulmonary function, by means of forced spirometry.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Within the first 30 days after recruitment.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Within the first 30 days after recruitment.

arm_group.description: Children aged between 8-12 years, with clinical diagnosis of mouth breathing
Children aged between 8-12 years old, with normal breathing

study_pop.textblock:
Mouth-breathing children were referred by Pediatrics Service (Federal University of Rio de Janeiro) and by School of Dentistry (Federal University of Rio de Janeiro), after the diagnosis of mouth breathing was confirmed.
Nasal breathing children were recruited from Tia Ciata Municipal School (Pra√ßa Onze-Rio de Janeiro, Brazil).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Nasal breathing (normal subjects group) or mouth breathing (mouth-breathing group), and the age between eight (08) and twelve (12) for both groups.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Prior physiotherapeutic treatment or in process, presence of diagnostic or report on acute or chronic pulmonary disease, neurofunctional or cognitive impairment and alteration of the osteomuscular system.
